title: The Root Schema
description: The root schema comprises the entire JSON document.

application.title: The Application Schema
application.description: Required Field: The application name for the manifest to be deployed.

version.title: The Version Schema
version.description: Required Field: Application Version to be deployed

regions.title: The Regions Schema
regions.description: Optional field, If no region is provided, we support deploying to all regions. Regions in which the application can be deployed. We support multiple region deployment.

asset_insight_id.title: The Asset_insight_id Schema
asset_insight_id.description: Required Field: Application Asset Id as generated for application by Insight

compute.title: The Compute Schema
compute.description: A compute resource could be a containers, lambda functions that make up the application.

custom_alarm.statistic: What function to use for aggregating. 'Minimum' | 'min' - “Maximum” | “max” - “Average” | “avg” - “Sum” | “sum” - “SampleCount | “n” - “pNN.NN”
custom_alarm.evaluate_low_sample_count_percentile: Optiona: Specifies whether to evaluate the data and potentially change the alarm state if there are too few data points to be statistically significant. Used only for alarms that are based on percentiles

containers.title: The Containers Schema
containers.description: If application service is containerized, then container image can be deployed. A container image can be scheduled to run in fixed interval with days, hours and minutes as unit of schedule. Container image can be scheduled to run based on cron expression as well.

items.title: The Items Schema
items.description: Tag of Container image in ECR or Dockerhub

name.title: The Name Schema
name.description: Name of the container service that needs to be deployed

artifact.title: The Artifact Schema
artifact.description: Image name from ECR or dockerhub or BAMS

build_tag.title: The Build_tag Schema
build_tag.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

schedule.title: The Schedule Schema
schedule.description: A container image or function can be scheduled to run in fixed interval or based on cron expression

type.title: The Type Schema
type.description: Type to indicate fixed_interval or cron expression

value.title: The Value Schema
value.description: In case of fixed_interval, this field is numerical value.

unit.title: The Unit Schema
unit.description: In case of fixed_interval, unit could be days, hours or minutes. 'value' and 'unit' is considered to configure fixed_interval schedule event

items.title: The Items Schema
items.description: Functions can be scheduled to run on a fixed interval or in intervals as defined by cron expression.

name.title: The Name Schema
name.description: The name of the function to be scheduled.

source.title: The Source Schema
source.description: The compressed file to be deployed for the lambda function

version.title: The Version Schema
version.description: The version of the function represented by the zip file

schedule.title: The Schedule Schema
schedule.description: An optional schedule that can be used to trigger the function in fixed interval or as represented by cron expression.

type.title: The Type Schema
type.description: schedule can be fixed_interval or cron expression

value.title: The Value Schema
value.description: Value can be cron expression or a numerical value for fixed interval type

unit.title: The Unit Schema
unit.description: In case of fixed interval the unit can be one of days or hours or minutes.

resources.title: The Resources Schema
resources.description: We currently support 2 app resoure types - s3 or dynamodb resources that the deployed application (containers or lambda functions can access to

items.title: The Items Schema
items.description: Schema for S3 or dynamodb. This can be expanded to other types

s3.title: The S3 Schema
s3.description: Application supported resoures s3 or dynamodb

items.title: The Items Schema
items.description: Defines the bucket name and versioning flag to be enabled or disabled. other flags are internal

enable_versioning.title: The Enable_versioning Schema
enable_versioning.description: Enable or disable versioning for the bucket

table_name.title: The Table_name Schema
table_name.description: Dynamodb Table name that application depends on

hash_key_name.title: The Hash_key_name Schema
hash_key_name.description: Hash Key or Partition key: A simple primary key, composed of one attribute known as the partition key. Attributes in DynamoDB are similar in many ways to fields or columns in other database systems.

hash_key_type.title: The Hash_key_type Schema
hash_key_type.description: Hash Key or Partition schema type Numeric or String or Binary

range_key_name.title: The Range_key_name Schema
range_key_name.description: Partition key and (Range key) sort key: Referred to as a composite primary key, this type of key is composed of two attributes. The first attribute is the partition key, and the second attribute is the sort key.

range_key_type.title: The Range_key_type Schema
range_key_type.description: Range key or sort-key - Partition key and sort key: Referred to as a composite primary key, this type of key is composed of two attributes. The first attribute is the partition key, and the second attribute is the sort key.

ttl.title: The Ttl Schema
ttl.description: Time To Live (TTL) for DynamoDB allows you to define when items in a table expire so that they can be automatically deleted from the database. The advantage of using epoch format (Number) is that you can use the TTL feature and all filters.

enabled.title: The Enabled Schema
enabled.description: Time To Live (TTL) for DynamoDB allows you to define when items in a table expire so that they can be automatically deleted from the database. The advantage of using epoch format (Number) is that you can use the TTL feature and all filters.

attribute_name.title: The Attribute_name Schema
attribute_name.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

local-indexes.title: The Local-indexes Schema
local-indexes.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

items.title: The Items Schema
items.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

name.title: The Name Schema
name.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

range_key.title: The Range_key Schema
range_key.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

projection_type.title: The Projection_type Schema
projection_type.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

non_key_attributes.title: The Non_key_attributes Schema
non_key_attributes.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

items.title: The Items Schema
items.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

global-indexes.title: The Global-indexes Schema
global-indexes.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.

items.title: The Items Schema
items.description: Global Secondary Indexes: Some applications might need to perform many kinds of queries, using a variety of different attributes as query criteria. To support these requirements, create one or more global secondary indexes and issue Query requests against these indexes in Amazon DynamoDB.

hash_key.title: The Hash_key Schema
hash_key.description: Global Secondary Indexe column Hash or partition key

range_key.title: The Range_key Schema
range_key.description: Global Secondary Indexe column Range or Sort key

projection_type.title: The Projection_type Schema
projection_type.description: A projection is the set of attributes that is copied from a table into a secondary index. The partition key and sort key of the table are always projected into the index; you can project other attributes to support your application's query requirements. When you query an index, Amazon DynamoDB can access any attribute in the projection as if those attributes were in a table of their own.

non_key_attributes.title: The Non_key_attributes Schema
non_key_attributes.description:
DynamoDB provides three different options for this:

KEYS_ONLY – Each item in the index consists only of the table partition key and sort key values, plus the index key values. The KEYS_ONLY option results in the smallest possible secondary index.

INCLUDE – In addition to the attributes described in KEYS_ONLY, the secondary index will include other non-key attributes that you specify.

ALL – The secondary index includes all of the attributes from the source table. Because all of the table data is duplicated in the index, an ALL projection results in the largest possible secondary index.

items.title: The Items Schema
items.description: An explanation about the purpose of this instance.
